timeline.headline:
Elizabeth Taylor
1932-2011
timeline.text:
The actress,renowned for her beauty, talent and eventful personal life, was one of the last stars left from Hollywood's golden age. A look at some of the milestones in her life.

This is demo prototype of this timeline tool. The test content orginates from The New York Time's interactive feature
Elizabeth Taylor: 1932-2011.

date.headline: Elizabeth Taylor Dies in Los Angeles

asset.caption: She died of congestive heart failure at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles.

date.headline: Reveals Congestive Heart Failure
date.text: Ms. Taylor disclosed that she had congestive heart failure,a disorder in which the heart

date.headline: Retires from Acting
date.text: Ms. Taylor, whose output steadily decreased beginning in the 1980s, announced her retirement from acting in 2003, saying she preferred to focus on her AIDS charity work.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: Receives Kennedy Center Honor
date.text: Ms. Taylor received a John F. Kennedy Center Honor in 2002.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: Introducing Dame Elizabeth Taylor
date.text: Ms. Taylor, a dual citizen of England and the United States, was appointed by Queen Elizabeth II as a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: Named a Top Hollywood Legend by AFI
date.text: Ms. Taylor was listed seventh on the American Film Institute's list of the greatest American female screen legends.

asset.caption: Ms. Taylor's eighth and final marriage was to Larry Fortensky

date.headline: Debut of Perfume Line
date.text: In the 1980s and 1990s, Ms. Taylor arguably became better known for her line of perfumes than her acting. Passion, her first licensed product, was released in 1987. White Diamonds followed in 1991.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: AIDS Activism
date.text: Ms. Taylor has been an energetic activist for AIDS-related causes.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: Makes Broadway Debut
date.text: Ms. Taylor made her Broadway debut in a revival of "The Little Foxes" by Lillian Hellman.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.
Ms. Taylor's seventh marriage

date.headline: Remarries Richard Burton
date.text: The second installment of the couple's marriage lasted less than 10 months. Ms. Taylor was also linked to Ardeshir Zahedi, the Iranian ambassador to Washington, during this time.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: Stars in 'Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'
date.text: Ms. Taylor won her second Academy Award for arguably her most acclaimed role.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.
Ms. Taylor left Eddie Fisher and married the actor Richard Burton.
The opulent production was among the most expensive in cinematic history at the time.

date.headline: Wins First Academy Award
date.text: Ms. Taylor won her first Oscar for her role in "Butterfield 8."

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: Stars in 'Butterfield 8'
date.text: One of Ms. Taylor's most acclaimed roles was as a call girl in the 1960 film "Butterfield 8."

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.
Ms. Taylor's fourth marriage.

date.headline: Nominated for an Oscar
date.text: Ms. Taylor received her first Academy Award nomination with a best lead actress nod for "Raintree County, " but she did not win. She was also nominated for best actress in "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" (1958); "Suddenly, Last Summer" (1959); "Butterfield 8" (1960); and "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" (1966).

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.
Ms. Taylor married Michael Todd,a film and theater producer.

date.headline: Stars in 'Giant'
date.text: In another acclaimed early performance, Ms. Taylor starred opposite Rock Hudson and James Dean in George Stevens's epic set in Texas.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: A Ubiquitous Starlet
date.text: Ms. Taylor's workload increased dramatically after "A Place in the Sun." In 1954, her busiest year, she appeared in four films: "Beau Brummell"; "Elephant Walk"; "The Last Time I Saw Paris"; and "Rhapsody."

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: Marriage to Michael Wilding
date.text: Ms. Taylor's second marriage, to Michael Wilding, an actor, also ended in divorce. They had two children: Michael Howard Wilding Jr. and Christopher Edward Wilding.

date.headline: A Child Star Grows Up
date.text: In the 1950s Ms. Taylor matured into adult roles and began to be considered one of the most beautiful women in the world. Her first acclaimed screen performance as an adult was as a socialite, opposite Montgomery Clift, in George Stevens's "A Place in the Sun" in 1951.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.
Ms. Taylor was married eight times to seven men.

date.headline: 'National Velvet' Makes Her a Star
date.text: Ms. Taylor became a child star after she played Velvet Brown in MGM's "National Velvet.

asset.caption: Elizabeth Taylor, with Earvin "Magic" Johnson, at an AIDS fundraiser in 1997.

date.headline: Screen Debut
date.text:
Ms. Taylor signed her first movie contract with Universal Pictures in 1941 and made her screen debut, at age 9, the following year in "There's One Born Every Minute."
Ms. Taylor signed with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer later in 1942 after Universal canceled her contract. "Lassie Come Home" (1943) was her first film for MGM; the studio went on to produce most of Ms. Taylor's most notable films.

date.headline: Born in London
date.text: Elizabeth Rosemond Taylor was born in London to American parents, Sara Warmbrodt (the actress Sara Sothern) and Francis Taylor. Ms. Taylor was a dual citizen of England and the United States. In 1939, when World War II began, the Taylors returned to America and eventually settled in Los Angeles.
